results.headline: On Other Side of the World, Life Is Still Upside Down
results.summary_short: Ying Liang’s slyly subversive second feature takes awhile to coalesce, but once it does, it becomes an intriguing exercise in juxtaposition.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ling Yi Ban

results.headline: A Journal of Sleeplessness, Recording a Fatal Illness
results.summary_short: It would be nice to say that “Fade” cures the very thing that it’s about, sleeplessness. But that wouldn’t convey the pretentiousness of this psychological drama.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fade

results.headline: Confronting a Killer Epidemic That Wouldn’t Die
results.summary_short: “Doomsday” has an appealing punk-rock sneer, but aside from a few clever music cues, swagger is, unfortunately, its only notable quality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Doomsday

results.headline: When a Satellite Makes a Scene
results.summary_short: David Hoffman’s documentary “Sputnik Mania” is an account of that Soviet satellite’s effect on the American consciousness.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sputnik Mania

results.headline: Remembering a Home for Music and Activism
results.summary_short: “Wetlands Preserved” is a fond account of the rising, thriving and eventual closing of the TriBeCa club known as the Wetlands Preserve.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wetlands Preserved

results.headline: When the Ghost in the Machine Is National Socialism
results.summary_short: Intriguing, frustrating, exasperating — the French film “Heartbeat Detector” succeeds best as a provocation.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Heartbeat Detector

results.headline: A Vicious Attack on Innocent People, on the Screen and in the Theater
results.summary_short: “Funny Games,” Michael Haneke’s first English-language film, subjects its viewers to a long spectacle of wanton and gratuitous brutality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Funny Games

results.headline: Hong Kong Crime Stories
results.summary_short: “Flash Point” plays like the last hurrah of a criminal underclass facing the inevitable shrinking of its bottom line.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flash Point

results.headline: Spinning Conflict
results.summary_short: “War Made Easy: How Presidents & Pundits Keep Spinning Us to Death” is a depressing look at political manipulation and news media compliance.
results.display_title: War Made Easy: How Presidents and Pundits Keep Spinning Us to Death

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of War Made Easy: How Presidents and Pundits Keep Spinning Us to Death

results.headline: On the Road to Nowhere in Down-and-Out America
results.summary_short: Filmed mostly in winter, in browns, grays and soiled whites, “Sleepwalking” sustains a mood of unrelenting bleakness, wearing its aesthetic of desolation like a badge of integrity.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sleepwalking

results.headline: Cliques and Fists
results.summary_short: “Never Back Down” offers extreme fighting as the modern-day alternative to sex, drugs and rock ’n’ roll.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Never Back Down

results.headline: Saving Who-Ville Is a Big Production
results.summary_short: What distinguishes “Horton Hears a Who!” from the other recent Dr. Seuss film adaptations is that it is not one of the worst movies ever made.
results.display_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who!

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who!

results.headline: Romance and Ransom in Colombia
results.summary_short: That someone is kidnapped in Colombia every three hours is a startling statistic that offers many cinematic possibilities. But “Towards Darkness” fails to use any of them to advantage.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Towards Darkness

results.headline: Race and Revenge in Lives of Father and Injured Son
results.summary_short: “Poor Boy’s Game” is a movie built around a boxing match, but its most powerful scenes involve no jabs or hooks.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Poor Boy's Game

results.headline: That Dashboard Light Now Casts Its Glow on Nostalgia
results.summary_short: “In Search of Paradise” portrays Meat Loaf as an obsessive, self-punishing performer, striving in vain to put on a live show that matches the visions in his head.
results.display_title: Meat Loaf: In Search of Paradise

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Meat Loaf: In Search of Paradise

results.headline: Imprisonment and Forced Servitude in Rural China
results.summary_short: “Blind Mountain,” the second feature from Li Yang, is a reminder that art sometimes keeps the truth alive far better than the news.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Blind Mountain

results.headline: On Ramps and Off, Free-Falling Through Time
results.summary_short: “Paranoid Park” is a haunting, voluptuously beautiful portrait of a teenage boy who, after being suddenly caught in midflight, falls to earth.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Paranoid Park

results.headline: Back to When Indies Were Cut-Rate and Gritty
results.summary_short: The worm turns and squirms in “Frownland,” an aptly named film made on the cheap in and around New York.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Frownland

results.headline: Rock ’n’ Roll Camp
results.summary_short: Young women find expression for more than their music in “Girls Rock!,” a jubilant documentary about a place where power chords and empowerment go hand in hand.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Girls Rock!

results.headline: Adventures of a Boy, His Dad and His Alien
results.summary_short: A devilishly entertaining curveball thrown at unsuspecting family audiences, “CJ7” is “E.T.” as reimagined by the premier clown of Chinese cinema.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of CJ7
